And also that the said I. • . his Executors, or Administrators, or some of them shall, and will before the Feast of &c deliver, or cause to be delivered unto the said T. W. his Executors, or Administrators, or some of them in the said
now dwelling house of the said T. W. aforesaid, the said Indenture of Covenants concerning the foresaid Marriage, cancelled or to be cancelled. In witnesse whereof the said Arbitrators to both parts of this present award indented, have set their hands and Seales, dated the, &c.

div.head: An Arbitrement, or award of Debt, made by an Earle upon submission by Bond.
div.p:
TO all true Christian people to whom this present writing of award indented shall come; The right Honourable G. Earle Marshall of England, &c. sendeth greeting &c. Whereas divers Suits, Variances, Controversies, and Debates heretofore have been had, moved, and depending between T. G. of T. in the County of I. Yeoman, on the one party, and F. M. of H. in the said County Gent. on the other party, for pacifying, ordering, and ending whereof the said I. G. and F.M. have bound themselves either to other in
the summe of foure hundred pound of, &c by their severall Obligations, bearing date, &c now last past, with condition there under written, to stand to, abide, performe, fulfill, and keepe the award, order, doome, judgement, and determination of the said Earle, indifferently elected, and chosen by the mutuall consent, and at the earnest and humble request, and petition of both the said parties, to arbitrate, award, order, judge, and determine of, for, and concerning all, and all manner of Actions, Suits, quarrels, debts, duties, and demands whatsoever, had, moved, or depending, or which hereafter might be had, moved, or depen • between the said parties, by reason of any matter, thing or things whatsoever accrued, or growne from the beginning of the World, untill the day of the date of the same Obligation; so that the same award were made in writing, indented under the hand and Seale of the said Earle before the nineteenth day of, &c. and the one part of the same writing indented,
delivered, or caused to be delivered by the said Earle to the said T. G. to his Executors, &c. or any of them, or to their, or any of their use, upon, or before the said nineteenth day of, &c. at, or in the now Mansion or Mannour House of the said Earle, called S. in, &c. and the other part thereof to the said F. M. &c. Ʋt supra, as by the said Obligations and Conditions thereof doth, and may more at large appeare Know you now, that the said Earle of his meere good will and favour, which he beareth to both the said parties, and of the great and honourable respect which he hath of their future quietnesse, taking upon him the charge and burden of the said award, and having deliberately at sundry times at large heard, and considered the griefes, allegations, and proofes of both the said parties, doth by these presents arbitrate; award, order, deeme, and judge of and concerning the premisses, in manner and forme following, viz. That the said F M. his &c. or
some of them, shall well and truly pay, or cause to be paid unto the said T. G. his, &c. or some of them, the summe of one hundred and sixty pound, of, &c. in the, &c. in manner and forme following, viz upon, &c. eighty pound thereof, and upon, &c other eighty pound thereof residue, and in full payment and satisfaction of the said summe of one hundred and sixty pound, and that in consideration thereof the said T. G. shall permit, and suffer all Suits, quarrels debts, duties, and demands, growne before the date of the said O • ligation to cease and be discontinued and no further prosecuted by him, or any other by his procurement. And furthermore for as much as the said F. M. is charged as is aforesaid, for the payment of the said sum of a hundred & sixty pound, partly by reason of a Judgement heretofore given for the said T. G. against one L. S. in the Q. Majesties Court, commmonly called, The Kings Bench, in an Action of Debt, in which the said T. G. hath recovered
against the said L. S. two hundred eighty five pound, and foure pence, as by the R • cord thereof, remaining in the said Court appeareth. His honour doth furtner award by these presents, in reliefe and ease of the said F. M. That if the said F. M. his, &c or any of them, doe well and truly pay, or cause to be paid the said summe of one hundred and sixty pound, according to the true meaning of this present award; And if the said L. S. his Heirs, &c. or some of them, shall not well and truly satisfie, content, and pay unto the said T. G. his, &c. the said severall summes above in this award appointed to be paid by the said F. M. before the severall dayes herein above mentioned; That then, and at all times after any such default of payment so to be made by the said L. S. his, &c. the said T. G. his, &c. shall permit and suffer the said F. M. his Executors, and Administrators, and every of them, at the costs and charges of the said F. M. his Executors, and Administrators, effectually
to prosecute, or cause to be prosecuted, all, and every such Execution, and Executions upon the said Judgement so had for the said T. G. against the said L. S. as to them, or any of them, or the learned Counsel of them or any of them shall seem good. And all and every sum and sums of mony thereby to be obtained to take, and convert to the onely proper use and behalfe of the said F. M. his Executors, and Administrators, without any account, recompence, or payment thereof, or therefore to be yeelded or made to the said T. G. his &c. or any of them, any thing in this present award conteyned, &c. notwithstanding. In witnesse whereof the said Earle to both the parts of this present award, hath set his hand and Seale, dated the, &c.

Note (Reader) all such Covenants and Conditions as are usually made for the assurance or enjoying of Lands or Tenements, Goods and Chattels may be inserted into awards, as shall seeme 〈◊〉 unto the Arbitrators 〈◊〉 parties.

div.head: Of notice of the Arbitrement.
div.p: ANd when the Arbitrators have made their award according to the submission, though they are not bound to give notice, but the parties are to take notice thereof at their owne perill, to save the forfeiture of their Bonds (as you shall finde the Law to be cleare in the first Tract of Arbitrements) yet it seemeth convenient and agreeable to equali • y and a good conscience that they should not be surprised, but that the Arbitrators should in due time before that either party be to performe any part thereof, give notice of the same unto them, lest otherwise they breake their Bonds and Covenants in that behalfe (if any such be) before they have knowledge of the same.

div.head: The finall cause and effects of Arbitrements.
div.p:
ANd thus by that which hath been set forth and discoursed in this and my former Treatise of Arbitrements, it doth evidently appeare, that the scope and end of Arbitrements and other Judgements is all one; and chiefly, the finall determination of Strifes, Suits, and Controversies, and so consequently their effects not much different. But the Law seemes more favourable to Arbitrements then other Judgements, insomuch as by Arbitrators the strict course and tedious ceremonies of Law Suits (which are wont most commonly to weary Suiters, and to dive somewhat too deepe in o their Purses) are cut off, and shorter decisions by them made, with little or no cost at all. But to make this good, this caveat (Reader) must be observed, lest this course prove as bad, if not worse then a Law Suit; that there be honest, indifferent, and
judicious Arbitrators chosen, not only such as are just men, but such as are skilfull and knowing in the matters in controversie, that their ignorance may not make them erre, and the parties suffer as much by their folly, as others no doubt have done by their Arbitrators injustice and knavery; for unequall and insufficient Arbitrements doe often cause tedious Suits, and those no small expence, so that this course which the people make choise of for their cure, proves often worse then the disease; but I have touched upon this before, and therefore this here shall suffice.

div.head: An Award made by an Arbitrator touching Copy-hold Land, between an Alderman of London and another.
div.p:
TO all Christian people, to whom this present writing of award indented shall come, H. T. of Lincolnes Inne, in the County of Middlesex Esquire, sendeth greeting in our Lord
God everlasting; Whereas Suit, Variance, and Debate heretofore hath been, and yet is had, moved, and depending, as well in the Queenes Majesties Court of Requests, as in divers other Courts, between R. H. Citizen and Alderman of London of the one party, and R. E. of K. in the County of M. Yeoman of the other party, of for, and concerning the right, • i • le, use interest, and possession of divers Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, with the Appurtenances, lying and being in K. within the Mannour or Lordship of T. within the said County of M. and conteyning by estimation about two hundred Acres of Land, Meadow, Pasture and Wood, commonly called or knowne by the name of Hehines Land; for the appeasing, finall end, and determination of all which said Suits, Variances, and Debates, the parties aforesaid have submitted and compromitted themselves to stand to, obey, and performe the Arbitrement, Ordinance, Doome, and Judgement of the said H. T. Arbitrator,
indifferently elected, named, and chosen by both the said parties, indifferently to Arbitrate, Order, Deeme, Award, and Judge, as well of, for, and concerning the estate, right, title, interest use, and possession of all and singular the said Premises, and every part and parcell thereof; as also of, for, and upon all manner of Actions, Suits, quarrels, Debts, Debates, Trespasses, and demands whatsoever heretofore had, moved, stirred or depending between the said parties from the beginning of the World untill the twentieth day of November last past, as by their severall writings Obligatory, wherein either of the said parties stand bounden to the other of the same parties in the summe of two hundred pound, bearing date the said twentieth day of November, and made for the true performance of the said award, more at large it doth and may appeare Whereupon • he said •… . H. having taken upon him the charge and burden of the said Arbi
•… rement, and having pr • s • nt before
him both the said parties, and having also very advisedly weighed and considered the ti • les, claimes, allegations, and proofes of either of the said parties to the said Premises; And upon sight and due consideration of all the Evidences, Writings and proofes shewed and made before me the said H. T. by both the said parties doe Award, Arbitrate, Order, Deeme, and Judge of the Premise •… in manner and forme following▪ that is to say: First, I the said Arbitrator doe Award, Deeme, Order and Judge, that the said R. E. or hi •… Heires, at all times within thre •… yeares next ensuing the date of thes •… presents, upon lawfull and reasonable warning by the Steward, Bayliffe or Reeve of the said Mannour o •…
T. for the time being, shall at th •… next Court so to be holden, ther •… next after such warning had, surrender and give up into the hand •… of the said R. H his Heires or Assignes in open Court, according to the Custome of the said Mannour to the use of the said R. H. and hi •…
Heires for ever, all and singular the aforesaid Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments hereafter in these presents mentioned, expressed, and declared, that is to wit; one Mansion or dwelling House, wherein the said R. E. now dwelleth, with all Edifices and Buildings, &c. And furthermore, I the said H. T. doe award, ordaine, deeme, and judge by these presents, that the said R. H. his Heires or Assignes at the said Court, where and when the said Surrender shall be so made, shall assure and convey unto the said R. E. or to his Heires, that shall so surrender the Premises as aforesaid by Copy of Court Roll, according to the custome of the said Mannour, or •… therwise as by the said R. E. his Heires and Assignes, or any of them, or by his or their learned Counsell, shall be resonably devised or advised, •… nd at the proper costs and charges of the said R. E. his Heires and Assignes, not altering by the said •… ssurance or assurances so to be de
•… ised or advised as is aforesaid, any
Custome, Liberty, or Jurisdiction of the said Lordship, Mannour, o •… other the Premises, with all and singular the said Lands, Tenements, an •… Hereditaments, and all other th •… Premises, with their appurtenance whatsoever, before by these present ordered, and judged to be surrendered as is aforesaid (foure Acres o •… Land now in the occupation of, &c parcell of the Premises to be chose •… by the said R. H &c. onely excepted and sore-prized) to have and t •… hold the same Lands, Tenements and all other the Premises with th •… appurtenances (except before excepted) unto the said R. E. and t •… his Heires Males, incorrupt with in the fourth degree of Consanguinity, according to the ancien •… Custome of the said Mannour. An •… if it happen that the said R. E. do •… decease before the said Surrende •… made as is aforesaid, Then to hav •… and to hold the said Premises with the appurtenances, to th •… Heires of the said R. E. which so shall surrender the same, and to
his Heires males incorrupt within the fourth degree of Consanguinity, &c.

div.head: An Award, reciting that either of the Parties stand bound to other to performe the Award, and that the Award is made before the prefixed time in the Obligation, and with the full consent of both the parties.
div.p:
TO all Christian People, to whom this present writing indented of award shall come, R. W. and R. C. send greeting in our Lord God everlasting. Know yee, that whereas Varience, Strife, Debate, and Controversie hath heretofore been had, moved, and stirred between A. B. of C. and D. E. of F. of, for, and concerning the right, title, interest, use, possession, and occupation of &c. for the appeasing and ending whereof, either of the said parties by their mutuall assents, consents, and agreements, have submitted, compromitted, and bound
themselves either to other by their severall writings Obligatory, bearing date, &c. in the summe of, &c to stand to, abide, obey, observe, performe, fulfill, and keepe the Award, Arbitrament, Ordinance, Doome, and Judgement of us, &c. Arbitrators indifferently elected, and chosen between the said parties to arbitrate, order, &c. of, and for the Premises, as by the said severall Obligations, with conditions for the performance thereof more at large appeareth. Whereupon we th •… said Arbitrators taking upon us th •… labour, businesse, and charge of the same award, and willing to set the said parties at a finall peace, unity, and concord, for, and concerning the Premises, have by good advice and deliberation seen, heard, and throughly examined both their titles, allegations, evidences, an •… proofes, in, and to the said Premises; and thereupon before the day and time appointed unto us by the said Obligations, for the making, giving up, and finishing of the said
Award; we the said Arbitrators by and with the full Assent, Consent, and Agreement of both the said parties, do make, publish, declare; and give up this our present Award betweene the said parties of, for, and concerning the premisses, in manner and form following: First, we award, ordaine, deeme, and judge, That &c. Also we award &c. And finally, we award, ordaine, deeme, and judge, &c. In witnesse whereof we the said Arbitrators, and also both the said parties to the Award, have interchangeably put our Hands and Seales, the tenth day of &c. in the twentieth yeare of the Reigne of &c. by the grace of God of England &c. King, Defendor of the Faith, &c.

div.head: Quaeries. Certaine Quaeries or doubtfull Cases collected by the same Author out of our old and new Bookes, and put under their proper Heads or Titles, together with the Books cited pro and contra, very usefull and necessary for all Students in the Law.
Acceptance.
div.p: A Man makes a Feoffement upon condition of reinfeoffement, whether acceptance of another estate than is contained in the Condition, shall be a Dispensation of the Condition, or not? Quaere. And see Title Conditions. 9.

A Bishop makes a Lease for yeares rendring Rent, after makes a new
Lease, with confirmation of the Deane and Chapter, and dies, if by his death the first Lease be void, so that the Successor cannot make it good by acceptance of the Rent, or not. Quaere. 32 H. 8. Dyer. fo. 46. pl. 9.

Tenant in taile makes a Lease for yeares to commence after his death, rendring rent, and dies, the issue Accepts the Rent. Whether this shall barre his entry or not? Quaere. Dyer. fo. 279. a. pl. 7. fo. 69. pl. 30. fo. 246. a. pl. 69. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 44. a. Pl. Com. fo. 430. & 437. a.

Tenant in taile makes a Lease for yeares rendring 20 s. Rent, and after releases 19 s. and dies, and the Issue accepts the 12 d. whether he may distraine for the 19 s. more or not? Quaere 13 & 14. of the Queene Dyer. fo. 304. pl. 53.

div.head: Accord.
div.p: WHether an Accord with satisfaction be a good Plea in an Attaint, or not, Quaere 13. E. 4. 1. Br. Attaint. 91. 13. E. 4. 5. Br. Attaint. 118. 35. H. 6. 30. Br. Attaint. 12. 6. E. 6. Dyer. fo. 75. pl. 27. 6. Rep. fo. 44. a.

div.head: Acquittance.
div.p: A Man bargaines and sels a Manour for 20 l. solvend. at such a Feast; and in the Indenture there are divers Covenants; for observance of all which Covenants and Payments, he bindes himselfe in 40 l. whether in debt for this, the Defendant may plead payment without an Acquittance, or not? Quaere 26. H. 8. Dyer. fo. 6. pl. 3. 28. H. 8. Dyer. fo. 25. pl. 160.

div.head: Administrator and Administration.
div.p: AN Executor payes 20 s. for the Testator, and retaines a horse of the Testators of the same value; whether this be an Administration or not? Quaere 21. E. 4. 21. Br. Title Administration 37.

Whether Probate of a Will, or taking Letters of Administration without doing of any more, shall be said an Administration or not? Quaere 26. H. 8. 7. Br. Administration 2. 20. H. 6. 1. Br. Administration 5. 34. H. 6. 14. Br. Administration 7. 37. H. 6. 27. Br. Administration 31.

div.head: Annuity.
div.p: WHether an Annuity may be granted over, or not? Quae e 41. E. 3. 27. Br. Annuity 8. 19. H. 6. 42. Br. Annuity 19 21. E. 4. 20. Br. Annuity 37. 14. H. 4. 5. Br. Deputy, &c. 4.

Whether a release of Actions reals, be a barre in an Annuity or not? Quaere 2. H. 4. 13. Br. Annuity 43. 11. H. 4. 85. Br. Debt. 66. See Dyer. fo. 24. pl, 149. an inheritance in a nomine paenae. See Davis Reports, fo. 6. a. and Title Releases 2.

div.head: Appeale.
div.p: A Man for Felony adjudged to death, and pardoned, is after put to answer to an Appeale of Felony, for a Felony done before, and whether he may or no? Quaere: For the Appeale was once determined, Br. Appeale 10. 6. H. 4. 6. Br. Corone 11. & 147. Br. Charter of pardon. 44.
Whether a Release of all Actions Reall and Personall, be a Barre in an Appeale of death, or not? Quaere. Littleton, Sect, 500. 9. H. 4. 2. Br. Tit. Appeale 29

An Appellor dies within the yeare, whether the Appeale shall descend to
others or not? Quaere. 11. H. 4. 11: Br. Appeale 30. 9. H. 7. 5. Br. Appeale 88. 17. E, 4. 1. Br. Appeale 104. 38 H. 6. 13. Br. Appeale 141. 9 H. 7. 5. Br. Appeale 144. 16. H. 7. 15. Br. Appeale 156. Dyer. fo. 69 pl. 31.

A woman who hath Title of an Appeale. De morte viri, takes husband, she loses her Appeale; but if the woman convicts the Defendant, and then takes husband, whether in such case she may demand execution or not? Quaere. 1. M. 1. Br. App • ale 100 21. E. 4. 72. 73. Br. Appeale 112. 11. H. 4. 48. Br. Appeale 148.

div.head: Apportionment.
div.p: A Man makes a Lease for yeares of Land, and of a stock of Sheepe, rendring certaine Rent, all the Sheep die, whether the Rent shall be apportioned or not? Quaere. 35. H. 8. Dyer. fo. 56 pl. 15 12. H. 8. fo. 11. b. pl. 5. 5. Rep. fo. 17. a. Spencers Case. 7. H. 7. 4. & 5. Br. Appertionment. 24. 4. of the Queene Dyer. fo. 212. pl. 37, 38.

div.head: Arbitrement.
div.p: WHether Arbitrators may arbitrate Free-hold or not? Quere. 14, H. 4. 18. & 19. Br. Arbitrment. 15. 12. Ass. pl. 25. Br. Arbitrement 30. 21. E. 3. 26. Br. Arbitrement. 53. See my first Treatise of Arbitrements, in the beginning thereof.

A man is bound to stand to the Arbitrement of I. N. who arbitrates that he shall pay 10 l. whether the obligee may have debt upon the Obligation, and upon the Arbitrement also, or not? Quaere. 33. H. 62. Br. Der 23. See my Treatise of Arbitrements abovementioned.

div.head: Arrearages.
div.p:
A Man recovers a Mannour in a Precipe quod reddat, and doth not sue execution in a yeare or two, and after sues execution, whether he shall
have the Arrerages and Services due after the Judgement or not? Quaere. 48. E. 3. 16. Br. Arrearages 5. See the like Case immediately following.
Grantee of a Rent Charge in Fee distraines for Arrerages, and then grants it over, whether the Arrerages be lost or not by the Assignement. Quaere. See my Rep. pa. 103. pl. 178.

A man who hath Title of Entry for non-payment of Rent upon a Lease doth not enter by the space of a yeare or two after the forfeiture, what remedy for the Rent incurred after the Title of entry. Quaere. 6. H. 7. 3. Br. Arrearages 11.

div.head: Assets by discent, and Inter-maines.
div.p: LAnd descends to an Heire, and he aliens it and after re-purchases it, whether it shall be Assets or not▪ Quaere. 26. H. 8. 1. Br. Assets, &c. 1. & 27.

Land of 40 s. a yeare discends charged with the Rent of 26 s. by a yeare, this is not Assets of 40 s. tamen hoc videtur; where the charge is of an estate of Freehold, but here the Charge is but a Chattell, and the Freehold not charged. Ideò Quaere. 43. E. 3. 9. Br. Assets. 9.

Whether a Reversion shall be Assets in Debt, or a Formedon; or a rent upon a Lease for life, shall be Assets in a Formedon or not? Quaere 40. E. 3. 38. Br. Assets 12. 7. H. 6. 3. & 4. Br. Assets. 17. 16. E. 3. Br. Assets. 23. 38. E. 3. 32. Br. Assets 30. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 374. b.

An Executor payes a Debt of his proper goods, and retains goods of the Testators to the value, whether these shall be Assets or not? Quaere. 21. E. 4. 21. 22. Br. Assets. 6. 20. H. 7. 4. & 5. Br. Assets inter maines. 12. See Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 283. a.

Whether a Tenancy escheated after the death of the Ancestor, shall
be Assets to the Heire, for to barre him by a Warranty or not? Quere. Keilway. 104. pl. 14. See Perkins, fo. 20. b. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 117. a. and 30. H, 8. Dyer. pl. 15.
If an Executor release a Debt or discharge one in Execution, whether this shall amount to as much as Assets received or not? Quare. Hobarts Rep. pa. 81.

div.head: Attachment of Goods.
div.p: WHether an Attachment in Court Baron be forfeited by the non-appearance of the party or not? Quaere 28. H. 6. 9. Br. Attachment 2. 34. H. 6. 49. Br. Attachment 19.

div.head: Attaint.
div.p:
WHether an Attaint lyes in a Writ of Redisseism or not? and whether the Redisseism be more than an Inquest of Office? Quaere. 18.
H. 8. 1. Br. Attaint. 1. 2. H. 4. 2. Br. Attaint. 22. 40. Ass. pl. 23. Br. Attaint. 79 11, Rep. Sir Jo. Heydons Case.
Whether an Attaint lyes in a Writ of inquiry of waste or not? Quaere. 48. E. 3. 19. Br. Attaint. 21. 2. H. 4. 2. Br. Attaint. 22. 11. Rep. Sir John Herdons Case.

In an Attaint one of the Petty Jury pleades an Accord, with satisfaction made betwixt the Plaintiffe and the Defendant, whether an Accord with satisfaction be a good Plea in an Attaint, and whether the petty Jury may plead that which is betwixt the Plaintiffe and Defendant or not? Quaere. 13. E. 4. 1. Br. Attaint. 91. 13. E. 4. 5. Br. Attaint. 118.

div.head: Atturnement.
div.p:
LEssee for life is disseised by the Grantee of the reversion, and after recovers in an Assize; whether this be an Attornement or not, Quaere
2. Rep, Tookers Case the latter end: Cooke upon Littleton fo. 319. a. 18. E. 3. 48. b. 6. Rep. 69. b. Sir Moyle Finches Case.

div.head: Bayle and Mainprize.
div.p: WHether the Bayle may render the body of the Defendant in the Common Bench after a Writ of Error brought by him? or Whether the Bayle be in this case forfeited or not? Quare. Hobarts Rep. pa. 157. pl. 142.

div.head: Baylie.
div.p: A Man distraines as Baylie, and is not Baylie, and after the Lord agrees to it, whether it be good or no? Quaere. 26. H. 8. 8. Br. Baylie, &c. 1. 7. H. 4. 30. Br. Baylie, &c. 4.

div.head: Baron and Feme.
div.p: BAron and Feme obligees, the Baron onely brings Debt, whether it will lye or not? Quaere. 3. H. 6. 36. Br. Baron and Feme, 2. 43. E. 3. 10. Br. Baron and Feme, 14. 39. E. 3 5. Br. Baron and Feme 55. 43. E. 3. 8. and 16. Br. Baron and Feme 64.

Baron and Feme bound in an Obligation of an 100 l. for a Release made to them of Land de jure uxoris, the Baron dies, whether this Obligation shall binde the Feme or no? Quaere. 44. E. 3. 33. Br. Baron and Feme, 77.
Whether a man may be bound to pay money to his wife or not? Quaere. for I doubt of it 27. H. 8. 27. Br. Conditions. 8. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 206. b.
Whether Baron and Feme may be Conspirators or not, Quaere. 38. E. 3. 3. Br. Conspiracy 14.
In an Avowry against a Baron and Feme, whether the Baron by himself, or whether the Baron and Feme together may disclaime or not, Quaere. See Title Disclaimer. 1.

div.head: Barre.
div.p: IN an Annuity the Defendant said that a Tenth was granted to the King by the Clergy, and these Arrearages were leavied by the Collector, as the portion of the Plaintiffe due to the King, Judgement, &c. whether this shall barre the Plaintiffe or not. Quaere. 21. H. 7. 12. and 16. Sr. Barre. 49. & 50.

Whether he which is barred in Debt against an Executor, upon a fully administred found against him, shall have a new Writ of Debt upon Assets come after or not Quaere. 4 H. 6. 4. Br. Debt 106. and Executors 85. 19. H. 6. 36. 37. Br. Executors 70. See the 8. Rep. fo. 134. a. b.

Tenant for life the Reversion to an Ideot, an Uncle Heire apparent to the Ideot leavies a Fine, and dies, Tenant for life dies, the Ideot dies; whether the issue of the Uncle who leavied the Fine shall be barred by it or not. Quaere. See my Rep. pa. 94. pl. 164. & pa. 146. pl. 216.

div.head: Cessavit.
div.p: LOrd Mesne and Tenant, the Mesne cesses in payment of Serv • ces by two yeares, and after purchases the Tenancy; whether a Cessavit lies against him or not. Quaete. Keilway Casus incerti temporis, fo. 104. pl. 15. See 27. H. 8. 28. Br. Cessavit. 1.

div.head: Champerty.
div.p: COuncell agrees with his Clyen •… before Action brought, that h •… shall have part for his wages, whether this be Champerty or not. Quaere. 12. H. 4. 26. 13. H. 4. 16. & 17. Br. Champerty 3.
The Statute speakes onely of Plea, and therefore whether Champerty lyes upon a Suit in a Subpaene or not. Quaere. 15. H. 7. 2. Br. Champerty 6.

div.head: Charge.
div.p: A Man makes a Lease for life, and charges the reversion which after comes to the Tenant for life by discent, whether he shall hold it charged or not. Quaere. 9. E. 4. 18. Br. Charge. 16. & 29. & Br. Estates. 25. See Dyer. fo. 141. pl. 44.
A Disseisor grants a Rent Charge, the Disseisee confirmes the Grant, and after enters upon the Disseisor, whether the Charge be avoided or not. Quaere. See Title Confirmation 2.

div.head: Charter of Pardon.
div.p: WHether a Pardon of the King of Felony, Homicide, &c. doth pardon Murder ot not. Quaere, See my Rep. pa. 213. pl. 250.

div.head: Clergie.
div.p: WHether a Bastard may have his Clergie or not. Quaere. 11. H. 4. 8 Br. Bastardy, 46. & Br. Clergie 22.
Whether a man captus oculis, shall have his Clergie or not. Quaere. Br. Clergie 21.

div.head: Commoner and Common.
div.p:
VVHether a man may borrow anothers Beasts; to take Seisin of Common, so that he chase them out presently, or not Qvaere. 45. E. 3. 25. Br. Commoner, &c. 5. 22.
Ass. pl. 84. Br. Commoner, &c. 40. & Br. Title seisin, 5. & 36.

div.head: Conditions.
div.p: A Man Covenants that his eldest Sonne shall marry the Daughter of another by such a day, and he dies before the day, whether the second Sonne that now is may perform the condition or not. Quaere. 27. H. 8. 14. 15. Br. Conditions 7.

Whether a release of a right, &c. upon a condition subsequent, be good or not. Quaere. 21. H. 7. 24. Br. Cond. 84. 17. Ass. pl. 2. Br. Cond. 103. 31. Ass. pl. 32. Br. Cond. 115. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 274. b. 43. Ass. pl. 12. Br. Releases 39.

A man is bound to infeoffe a woman by a day, and before the day he himselfe marries the woman, he may make a Lease for a moneth to a stranger, the remainder to his wife, and this is a good performance of the condition,
by Fisher tamen Quaere. 4. H. 7. 4. Br. Feoffements of Lands, 38.
A man makes B. & C. his Executors, proviso that B. shall not administer, whether this proviso be good or not. Quaere, See Title Executors 4.

A man makes a gift in taile upon condition that the Donee shall not make a Lease for three lives, or twenty one yeares, according to the Statute of 32. H. 8. whether this be a good condition or not. Quaere. 10. Rep. Cocke upon Littleton, fo. 223. a fo. 39. a, 33. H. 8. Dyer. fo. 48. 49.

Lessee for yeares Covenants and grants to the Lessor, that if he, his Executors or Assignes, alien the terme, that it should be lawfull to the Lessor and his Heires to enter the Lessee makes his wife Executrix and dies who takes husband, and the husband aliens, whether the Grant and Covenant made of the part of the Lessee bee a Condition or not Quaere. and whether the Condition be
broken by the alienation of the second husband or not. Quaere. 28. H. 8. Dyer. fo. 6. pl. 1. See Dyer. fo. 45. pl. 1. and 3.

A man makes a Lease for yeares, upon condition that if the Lessee during his life, assignes his terme, that it should be lawfull to the Lessor to re-enter, the Lessee devises it by his Testament, whether this be a breach of the Condition or not Quaere. 31. H. 8 Dyer. fo. 45. pl. 3.

Tenant in Taile makes a Feoffement upon condition to make back an Estate to him and his wife in taile, the remainder in M. Filio 〈◊〉 , &c. the remainder Sibill. filiae meae, the Feoffees make a Feoffement to the first Feoffer and his wife in taile, the remainder to T. M. Rilio • meo, the remainder Sibill. filiae meae, the Feoffor dies, and T. M. enters for Condition broken, 'twas holden that the Condition was broken because that Sibill. Filiae meae cannot be intended the Daughter of the first Feoffor, but whether the Condition be extinguished, or onely
suspended by the acceptance of the Feossor, this is the question, and of this Quaere. 31. H. 8. Dyer. fo. 45. pl. 4. 5. E. 6. Dyer. fo. 69. pl. 36. See 8. H. 7. 7. Br. Conditions 134. 22. E. 4. 17. Br. Conditions 167.
Lessee upon condition that he shall not do wast, he suffers wast, whether this be a breach of the Condition or not. Quaere. 10. and 11. of the Queen, Dyer. fo. 281. pl. 21.

Gavelkinde Land is devised to the eldest Sonne, upon condition that he shall pay 100 l. to the wife of the Devisor, he failes of payment, whether the younger Sonne may enter in the moity as by an implied limitation or not. Quaere. 14. & 15. of the Queene Dyer. fo. 316. pl. 5. See the 3. Rep. fol. 21. a. Borastons Case.
A man grants a Rent de novo in Fee, upon condition that the Grantee shall not alien, whether this be a good condition or not Quaere. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 223. c. See 2. Rep. fo. 70. 76. & 78.

div.head: Confirmation.
div.p: BAron and Feme Donees in speciall Taile, the Baron leavies a Fine, and dies, he in reversion confirmes to the wife her Estate, to have to her and to her Heires of her body by the husband ingendred, what is wrought by this Confirmation. Quaere. 9 Rep. Beaumonts. Case. See my Rep. pa. 146. pl. 216.

div.head: Copy hold.
div.p: THe King grants a Copy-hold for life Generally, whether this destroyes the Copy-hold or not. Quaere. my Rep. pa 206. pl. 246.

div.head: Corone, &c.
div.p:
A Man bailes goods to another to keepe, and after the owner that bailed them, takes them againe feloniously,
whether this be Felony or not. Quaere. 7. H. 6. 42. Br. Crrone 45. 5. H. 7. 18. Br, Corone 142. 29. H. 6. Br. Corone, 216. 13. E. 4. 9. Br. Corone 160.

Whether a man may feloniously steale goods in his owne custody or not. Quaere. 21. H. 7. 14. Br. Corone 58. 12. Ass. pl. 32. Br. Corone 76. 3. H. 7. 12. Br. Corone 137. 13. E, 4. 9. Br. Corone 160. See Dyer fo. 5. pl. 2. and See now the Statutes of 21. H. 8. cap. 7. and 5. of the Queene, cap. 10. by which 'tis made Felony for a Servant to steale goods in his custody to the value of 40 s. &c.

A man delivers an Obligation to his Servant to receive 20 l. of the Obligor, and the Servant receives it, and after runs away &c. whether this shall be Felony within the Statutes of 21. H. 8. and 5. of the Queene before cited or not. Qvaere. Because that the money was not delivered to him by his Master, as the Statutes speake. 25. H. 8. Dyer fo. 5. pl. 2.

Three men are appealed in Felony, two as principals, and the third as accessary, one of the principals is attainted, and the other not, whether the accessary may be arraigned before the Attainder of the other or not. Quaere. Keilway Casus incerti temporis. fo. 107. pl. 23.

div.head: Corporations.
div.p: VVHether a Corporation may retaine a Servant without Deed or not? and what Acts they may do without Deed, what not? Quaere. 14. H. 8. 〈◊〉 . 29. Br. Corporaoions 34. 4. H. 7. 17. Br. Corpor. 49. 4. H. 7. 6. Br. Corpor. 47. 7. H. 7. 9. Br. Corpor. 50. 12. H. 7. 25. 26. Br. Corpor. 51. 12. E. 4. 9. 10. Br. Corpor. 56. 18. E. 4. 8. Br. Corpor. 59. 21. E. 4. 76. Br. Corpor. 66. 18. E. 4. 8. Br. Corpor. 73. 13. H. 8. 12. Br. Corpor. 83. Pl. Com. 91. 92. 4. Rep. 119. 6. Rep. 38. 10. Rep. 67, 11. Rep. 79. Dyer. fo. 102. pl. 83.

The King grants a Manour homenibus de I. haeredibus & successoribus suis rendring Rent, whether this doth make them a Corporation or not 〈…〉
Quaere. And quaere if it had been without rendring any rent: See Tit. Grant •… of the King 1.

div.head: Covenant.
div.p: A Man Covenants for himselfe, not naming his Executors, whether this shall binde his Executors or not. Quaere. See Title Executors 2.

A. Covenants with B. to infeoffe him of the Mannour of D. before Easter, discharged of all former incumbrances, but Leases of which the antient Rent is reserved, after, and before the Feoffement, he makes new Leases rendring the antient Rent, whether this be a breach of the Covenant or not. Quaere 3. & 4. P. &. M. Dyer. fo. 139. pl. 34.

A man upon Covenants of Marri
•… ge, covenanteth that immediately •… ter his decease, the Land shall inure •… nd remaine to his Sonne, and whe
•… her this Covenant doth raise a use •… o the Sonne or not. Quaere. See Title •… ses 1.

div.head: Countermand.
div.p:
A Feme sole commands I. to make an Obligation in her name, and •… o deliver it as her Deed, and before •… he execution of it she takes husband, •… nd after 'tis executed, by some this •… hall binde her, because she had po
•… er tempore mandati. Quaere. whether it •… e not countermanded by the inter
•… arriage, 14. E, 4. 2. Br. Coverture, &c.
•… 0. 27. H. 6. 7. Br. Relation 1. 3. Rep. fo.
•… 5. b. 4. Rep. fo. 60. & 61. Perkins 140. •… 41.

Whether a Disseisin shall counter
•… and a devise or not. Quaere. 39. H. 6. •… 8. Br. Devise 15.

A Feme sole Licenses a man to hunt in her Warren, and after takes husband, whether by the inter-marriage the License be countermanded or not. Quaere 22. H. 6. fo. 52. Br. Licenser, &c. 6. 3. H. 8. Keilway, fo. 163. a. 4. Rep. fo. 60. & 61.
A Lease at will is made to a Feme sole who takes husband, whether by this the Lease be determined or not. Quaere. 3. H. 8. Keilway fo. 162. pl. 4.

div.head: Court Baron, County Court, and Hundred.
div.p: A Man brings debt upon a Recovery in Court Baron, whether the Defendant may plead nul tiel Record, or not, or whether he ought to say, nul tiel Recovery. Quaere. Br. Court Baron, &c. 1. 34. H. 6. 42. Br. Court Baron 14. 9. E. 4. 14. Br. Court Baron 16. See my Reports, pa. 15. pl. 35.

Upon a Recovery in debt in a Court Baron, the Baily cannot sell the Goods of the Defendant taken in execution,
except by custome, and whether he ought to keepe them as a distresse till the plaintiffe be satisfied of his Debt, or whether he may deliver them to the Plaintiffe in execution or not. Quaere. 22. Ass. pl. 27. Br. Court Baron, &c. 7. 38. E. 3. 3. Br. Court Baron 5. 4. H. 6. 17. Br. Court Baron 6. 1. E. 4. 10. Br. Court Baron 10.
A man brought Debt upon a Recovery in antient Demeasne, which is a Court Baron, whether the Defendant might wage his Law or not. Quare. See Br. Title wager of Law 10.
Whether a Hundred may be parcell of a Mannour or not. Quaere. 27. H. 6. 2. Br. Parcell &c. 2. & Br. scire facias 7. See Keilway, fo. 151. pl. 51.

div.head: Customes.
div.p:
BY the Custome of London a man cannot wage his Law for bourding, but notwithstanding in Debt brought at Westminster, the better opinion
seems to be, that there he shal •… have his Law, because that such customes are allowable onely in the places where they do arise. Tamen Quaere 1. E. 4. 5. Br. Customes 43.

The Inhabitants of a Parish have a Chappell of Ease, and a Custome that those within such a Precinct ought to finde a Rope for the third Bell, and to repaire part of the Mother Church, in consideration of which they have been freed from payment of any Tithes to the Mother Church, whether this be a good Custome or not. Quaere. See my Reports, pa. 91. pl. 151.

div.head: Damages.
div.p: WHether in Detinue for divers severall things, the Jury may give Damages in grosse, or whether they ought to give them severall or not. Quaere. 1. E. 5. 5. Br. Dam. 141. 1. R. 3 fo. 1. 3. H. 6. 43. Br. Detinue of Goods 4. & 48.

A man distraines for a penalty as
•… essed by Custome, and distrainable •… y Custome, and upon a Replevin •… rought, Judgement was given for •… he Avowant, and Damages assessed, •… d whether Damages ought to have •… een given or not. Quaere. See my Re
•… orts, pa. 38. pl. 64.

div.head: Darreine Presentment.
div.p:
A Man seized of a Manour with an Advowson appendant in right •… f his wife, presents, and after hath •… ssue, and the wife dies, the Church •… ecomes void, and he presents and is •… isturbed, whether he shall have an Assize of Darreine Presentment or •… ot. Quaere. Keilway Casus incerti tempo
•… is, fo. 118. b. pl. 61.

div.head: Debt.
div.p:
WHether the Heire of the Heire, or the Executors of the Heire •… hall be charged in debt upon an Obligation
made by the Ancestor or not. Quaere. Pl. Com. fo. 441. a.

A man is bound to stand to the Arbitrement of I. N. who arbitrates that he shal pay 10 l. whether the Obligee shall have Debt upon the Obligation, and upon the Arbitrement also. Quaere. 33. H. 6. 2. Br. Debt 23.

In Debt upon a Lease for yeares, the Defendant said that the Plaintiffe was bound to Reparations by Covenant and because that the Tenements were ruinous, he commanded him to amend the Tenements with the Rent, the which he did, Judgement if Action, &c. and whether this be a good Plea or not. Quaere. 34. H. 6. 17. Br. Debt 27. 14. H. 4. 27. Br. Debt 72. 12. H. 8. 1. Br. Debt 226.
Whether Debt lyes upon a Fine or an Amerciament in a Lee • e or not. Quaere. 7. H. 6. 12. Br. Debt 85. 9 E. 4. 40. Br. Debt 114. 10. H. 6. 7. Br. Debt 180. 11. H. 7. 13. Br. Debt 240.

A man promises 20 l. in Marriage with his D • ughter: whether debt lies for it or not. Quaere. 22. Ass. p. 70. Br. Deb •
•• 5 1 •
E. 4. 6. Br. Debt 161. 17, E. 4. 4. Br. Debt 162. 15. E. 4. 32. Br. Debt 105.

div.head: Deeds Inrolled.
div.p: WHether a Deed inrolled shall be avoided by Duresse or not. Quere. 21. E. 3. 43. Br. Faitz Inroll 3. 19. H. 6. 6. Br. Faitz In • oll 4. 7. E. 4. 5. Br. Faitz Inroll 11. 16. H. 7. 5. Br. Faitz Inroll 17.

div.head: Demands and demandable.
div.p: THe Mannour of B. extends into B. and D. and is demanded per nomen n • am t i in B. whether he shall recover onely that which is in B. or not. Quaere. 9. E. 4. 17. Br. Demand 50:

Grantee of a Rent to be paid at the house, and if the Rent be behinde,
and lawfully demanded at the House, then to be lawfull for the Grantee to distraine, whether a distresse upon the Land in such case be a sufficient demand or not. Quaere. See my Rep. pa. 147. pl. 218.

div.head: Dennizen and Alien.
div.p: AN English man goes beyond the Sea, and marries a Feme alien, whether this makes her of the Allegiance of the King and her Issue inheritable or not Quaere. Br. Denizen and Alien 21. See my Reports pa. 91. pl. 130.

div.head: Detinue of Goods.
div.p: A man findes Goods, and delivers them over before Action brought, whether this shall excuse him in an Action of Detinue brought against him for the Goods or not. Quaere. 27. H. 8. 13. Br. Detinue of Goods, 1. 39. H. 6. 2. Br. Detinue &c. 33. 12. E. 4. 8. Br. Detinue, &c. 40.
Whether Detinue for Beasts taken in Withernam lyes or not Quaere. 11. H. 4 10. Br. Detinue of Goods 18.

div.head: Disclaimer.
div.p: IN an Avowry against a Baron and Feme, whether the Baron and Feme may disclaime or not. Quaere. 35. H. 6. 10. Br. Disclaimer 6. 43. E. 3. 5. Br. Disclaimer 8. 10. E. 4. 2. Br. Desclaimer 27. 4. H. 5. Br. Disclaimer 36. 14. H. 4. 18. Br. Disclaimer 38, 21. H. 7. 20. Br. Disclaimer 43. 9. H. 6. 52. Br. Disclaimer 44. 14. H. 4. 18. Br. Disclaimer 46. 30. Ass. pl. 10. Br. Disclaimer 50.
A man avowes, and the Plaintiffe acknowledges the Avowry, whether in another Avowry he may disclaime or not. Quaere. 2. E. 4. 16. Br. Disclaimer 23.
Whether the Demandant may enter upon the Disclaimer of the Tenant or not. Quaere. 4. E. 4. 38. Br. Disclaimer 24. 5. E. 4. 1. Br. Disclaimer 25.

Lord Mesne and Tenant, the Mesne cannot disclaime in an Avowry, or he cannot lose the Land of the Tenant; but whether they may joyne in Disclaimer or not. Quaere. 12. E. 4. 16. Er. Disclaimer 30. 9 H. 6. 27. Br. Disclaimer 1. 21 E 4. 47. Br. Disclaimer 31. 12. E 4. 13. Br. Disclaimer 28. 13. E. 4 6 Br. Disclaimer 42.

div.head: Discontinuance.
div.p: GRandfather, Father, and Sonne, the Grandfather Tenant in Taile makes a Lease to another for his life, and dies, the Father grants the reversion in Fee, the Tenant for life Attournes and dies, the Grantee enters, and after the Father dies, whether this be a discontinuance to the Sonne or not Quaere. Keilway, fo. 120. pl. 68. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 333. See Dyer fo. 98. pl. 55. and Littleton, Sect. 637, 638.

Tenant in taile makes a Lease pur ante vie, the remainder to the Donee in Fee whether this be a Discontinuance
in Fee or not. Quaere. 28. H. 8. Dyer. fo. 8. pl. 15. & fo. 9. pl. 121.

div.head: Dispensation.
div.p: A Man makes a Feoffement upon condition of re-infeoffement, whether acceptance of another Estate than is contained in the Condition, shall be a dispensation of the breach of the condition or not. Quaere. See Title Conditions.

div.head: Diss • i • or and Disseisin.
div.p:
A Man enters upon the Possession of the King whether this shall be a disseisin to the Tenant of the Freehold or not Quaere 3 Ass.
〈◊〉
B • . Disseis •• & Diss •• s ••
55. 2. H. 4 10. Br. Disseiso • & Disseisin 4.
A Disseisee leavies a Fine to a stranger, whether this gives the right to the Disseisor or not. Quaere. See Title Fines of Lands. 2.

div.head: Distresse.
div.p: WHether a man upon a returne irreplegiable, may worke the distresse or not. Quaere. 10. & 11. of the Queene Dyer, fo. 280. pl. 14.
Grantee of a Rent Charge in Fee, distraines for Arrearages, and then grants it over, whether the Arrearages are lost or not. Quaere. See Title Arrearages.

div.head: Distribution.
div.p: WHether the Ordinary, after Debts and Legacies paid, may inforce a Distribution of the residue of the Estate or not. Quaere. See my Rep. pa. 65. pl. 162. & pa. 93. pl. 158. and see Hobarts Reports.

div.head: Dower.
div.p: A Man makes a Lease for yeares rendring Rent, and after takes wife and dies, whether she shall be indowed of the Rent as well as of the reversion, or not. Quaere. 1. E 6 Br. Dower 89 Perkins fo. 69. pl. 348. and Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 32. a.
Whether a Writ of Dower lies against the Committee of a Ward of the King and whether Assignement of Dower be good by him or not. Quaere. Keilway, fo. 133. pl. 112.

div.head: Duresse and Manasse.
div.p: WHether a Deed inrolled shall be avoided by Duresse or not. Quaere. See Title Deeds inrolled.

A man makes a Writing by Duresse or Manasse, and after he being at large, a Defeasance is made by Deed
indented betwixt the Obligor and Obligee, whether this shall estoppe the Obligor to say that it was made by Duresse, &c or not. Quae • e. See Title Estoppell.

div.head: Embasement of Monies.
div.p: WHere Monies shall be paid in silver imbased, and who shall beare the losse of it, and who not. Quaere. And see Title Monies, and Embasement of them, per tot.

div.head: Emblements.
div.p: BAron and Feme Joyntenants, the Baron sowes the Land with Corn and dies, whether the Feme or the Executors of the husband shall have the Corne Quaere. 8. Ass. pl. 21. Br. Emblements 15. 8. E. 3. 54. Dyer. fo. 316. pl. 2, Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 55. b.

div.head: Entry lawfull.
div.p: AN Infant assignes Dower to his mother, more than the third part, whether he may enter into the surplu • age at his full age or not, or whether he is put to his Writ of Admeasurement of Dower or not. Quaere. 21. H. 7. 29. Br. Entre congeable; 44. and Admeasurement, &c. 4.

A Man grants a Seigniory for life, the Tenancy escheates, a stranger enters and dies seized, Tenant for life dies, whether the entry of the Lord be taken away, or not. Quaere. Keilway, Casus incerti temp ris, fo. 114. pl. 50.

Tenant for life, the remainder for life, the remainder in fee, Tenant for life makes a Feoffement in Fee, whether he in the remainder for life may enter for the forfeiture or not Qvaere. See Title forfeiture of Lands.

div.head: Enfranchisement.
div.p: A Nise marries a Freeman, whether by this she be infranchised for ever, or for life onely. Quaere. And if the Lord marries his Niese, whether this be an Infranchisement for ever or not. Quaere. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 123. a. & fo. 136. b. & 137. b. F. N. B. 78. b. 30. E. 1. Title Villein 46. 33. E. 3. ibid. 21. Doct. & Stud. fo. 140. a. 18. E. 2. ibi. 30. 46. E. 3. 6. 4. E. 4. 25. 1. H. 4. 6. 13. E. 1. Villen. 36. 18. Ass. 10. Mirror 10. 2. Sect. 18.

div.head: Error.
div.p: A Man recovers by Judgement erronious, and dies without Heire, what remedy. Quaere. 9. H. 6. 46. Br. Error. 9.

Error brought in the Kings Bench upon a Judgement given in an Assize one of the Plaintiffs in the Writ of
Error, dies pending the Writ, and notwithstanding Judgement was reversed, upon which the Recoverers in the first Action brought Error in the Kings Bench, and whether this Error lyes upon a Judgement given in the same Court or not. Quaere. 2. R. 3. 1. a. and 20. b. 7. H. 6. 28. Dyer. fo. 196. pl. 39. Br. Error 68. 15. H. 4. 7. Br. Error 81. 4 E. 4. 41. Br. Error. 158. Dyer. fo. 159 pl. 35.
Whether a Writ of Error lyes in an Ejectione firmae, before Judgement given upon the Writ of enquiry, or not. Quaere. See my Reports, pa. 88. pl. 142.

div.head: Escape.
div.p:
IF a man who is in Execution be let at large by Commandment of the King, Treasurer, or Chancellor or by License of the Chiefe Justice, whether this be an Escape or not. Quaere. 4. & 5. P. & M. Dyer fo. 162. pl. 50. 10. of the Queene Dyer fo. 275. pl.
46. 12. & 13. of the Queene Dyer. fo 279. pl. 24. Keilway, fo. 214. a. and many other Bookes. See Br. Escape.

div.head: Escheate.
div.p: A Tenant is disseised, and dies without Heire, whether the Lord may have a Writ of Escheate or not, because that the Tenant died not seized. Quaere. Or whether he may enter or not. Quaere. 2. H. 4. 8. Br. Escheate, 4. 7. H. 4. 17. Br. Escheate 5. 4. H. 6. 29. Br. Escheate 10. 37. H. 6. 1. Br. Escheate 11. 6. H. 7. 9. Br. Escheate 16. & 22. 32. H. 6. 27. Br. Escheate 26. F. N. B. 144. C. Keilway, fo. 114. a. See the 3. Rep. fo. 2. & 3.

div.head: Estates.
div.p:
A Man recovers a Rent by a Writ of Entry against Tenant in taile of a Rent, which had not being before the Grant made in taile, whether the Recoveror hath a Fee
simple or not. Quaere. 15. E. 4. 6. &
•… See 37. H. 6. 36. & Com. 557. a. See
•… itle Rents 2.

div.head: Estop • ell.
div.p:
A Man makes a writing by Duresse ot Manasse, and after he •… ing at large, a defeasance is made •… y Deed, indented betwixt the Ob
•… gor and the Obligee, whether this •… all estoppe the Obligor to say that •… was made by Duresse, &c. or not.
•… uere. 35. H. 6. 18. Br. Defeasance 17.
•… nd Estoppell 21. And the Question is •… o other, but whether the recitall of •… he obligation by the Deed indented •… defeasance, shall be an Estoppell •… r not, and for this, see 9. H. 6. 8. 9. •…
Estoppell, 5 35. H. 6. 33. Br. Estoppell
•… 3. 46. E. 3. 12. & 13. Br. Estoppell 43. •… 8. E. 3. 14. 15. Br. Estoppell 49. 18. Ass.
•… . 3. Br. Estoppell 127. 9. H. 7. 2. 21. •… . 4. 52. 53. Br. Estoppell, 173. See Cooke
•… pon Littleton, fo. 352. b.

div.head: Executors.
div.p: WHether Executors shall hav •… the Glasse of windowes o •… not. Quaere. 21. H. 7. 26. Br. Chattel •… &c. 7.

A Man Covenants for him, no •… naming his Executors, whether thi •… shall binde his Executors or not. Quaere. 32. H. 6. 32. Br. Covenant 28. 10. H. 7. 18. Br. Covenant 50. See Dyer. fo. 14. pl. 69 fo. 114. pl. 60. & fo. 322. pl. 25. See Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 209. a.

Whether he which is barred in Debt against an Executor upon a fully administred found against him, shall have a new Writ of Debt upon Assets come after or not Quaere. 4. H. 6. 4. Br. Debt, 106. & Executors 85. 19. H. 6. 36. 37. Br. Executors 70. 33. H. 6. 23. & 24. Br. Executors 18. 34. H. 6. 22. & 23. Br. Executors 22. See the 8. Rep. fo. 134. a. b.

A man makes B. and C. his Executors, proviso that B. shall not administer, whether this proviso be good or not. Quaere. 19. H. 8. 3. Br. Executor 2. 3. H. 6. 67. Br. Executor. 9. Dyer. fo. 3. pl. 7. 32. H. 8. Br. Executor 155.

The goods of the Testator are taken out of the possession of the Executors, whether they ought to joyne or sever in Action. Quaere. 42. E. 3. 26. Br. Executors 31. 2. H. 7. 15. 6. H. 7. 6, Br. Executors 170. 24. E. 3. 35. Br. Executors. 84.
An Executor grants omnia bona & catalla sua, whether this passes the goods of the Testator or not. Quaere. See Title Grants. 1.

Whether Executors shall be charged as Executors in Detinue brought against them upon a baylement made to their Testator or not. Quaere, Keilway, fo. 118. pl. 62. 3. H. 6. 35. Br. Executors 10. 41. E. 3. 30. 31. Br. Executors 28. 39. E. 3. 5. Br. Executors 92. See the 9. Rep. fo. 94.
Administration is committed to an Executor de son tort, whether he shall be charged as Executor, or as Administrator. Quaere. Keilway, fo. 127. pl. 91. 9. E. 4. 33. 47. Br. Executors 90.

Whether Debt lyes against an Executor of an Administrator, or not. Quaere. 32. H. 8. Dyer fo. 47. pl. 12. 34. H. 6. 14. Br. Administration. 7. 24. E. 3 54. Br. Executors 83. See 1 & 2. P. & M. Dyer. fo. 112. pl. 51. & 4. & 5. P. & M. Dyer. fo. 160. pl. 42. 1. & 2. of the Queene Dyer. fo. 174. pl. 21.
Whether the Executors of the Heire shall be charged in Debt upon an Obligation made by the Ancestor or not. Quaere. See Title Heire 1.
Whether the Executor of a Phillizer shall have the profits of the Writs which are to be subscribed with his name, or his Successor. Quaere. See my Reports pa. 90. pl. 147.

div.head: Extinguishment and Suspension
div.p: WHether unity of possession shall extinguish a way or passage or not, Quaere. 3. H. 6. 31. Br. Chymin. 13. 11. H. 4. 5. Br. Extinguishment &c. 11. 21. E. 3. 2. Br. Extinguishment 15. See 11. H. 7. 25. Br. Extinguishment 60. Hobarts Reports, pa. 171. pl. 170. Dyer, fo. 295. pl. 19.

A man Obligor marries with the Obligee, and after they are divorced, whether the Obligation be revived or not. Quaere. 26: H. 8. 7. Br. Co • erture, &c. 82. and Extinguishment 1. Dyer, fo. 13. a. 11. H. 7. 4. b. Br. Deraignement & Divorce 1. & 18. Hobarts Reports pa. 14. pl, 19. 8. Rep. fo. 136. a. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 264. 6. Dyer, fo. 140. a. Pl. Com. fo. 184. Keilway, fo. 122. b. 21. H. 7. 23. See Br. Assets by Discent. 1.

Land of B. out of which Rent is issuing, is given to another by Act of Parliament, whether the Rent be by this extinguished or not. Quaere. 21.
H. 7. 3. Br. Parliament, &c. 28.

A Feme sole makes a Lease for yeares, the Lessee commits waste, and after the Lessor and the Lessee intermary, and after are divorced, whether the action of waste be revived againe or not. Quaere. Keilway, fo. 122. pl. 75. See supra, pl. 2.
Where a Condition shall be extinguished, and where onely suspended. See Title Conditions 9.

div.head: Feoffements of Lands.
div.p: A Feoffment made by one joyn-tenant to his Compagnion, shall inure by way of confirmation by Newton. Quaere. 22. H. 16. 42. 43. Br. Confirmation 11. See Br. Feoffements, &c. ult.

A man makes a Feoffement of the Mannour of D. in D. eum pertinentiis, whether the Mannour of D. extending into D. and S. or nothing but that
which is in D. onely, or whether all the Mannour shall passe or not. Quaere. 7. H. 4. 27. Br. Feoffements of Lands, 55. 9. E. 4. 6. & 17. Br. Feoffements, &c. 59.

Whether a man surdus & mutus may make a Feoffement or not. Quaere. 34. & 35. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 55. pl. 12. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 42. b. Perkins Title Grants pl. 25. 2. H. 4. 8. Br. Feoffements &c. 7.

div.head: Fines leavied of Lands.
div.p: WHether by a Grant of conusance of Ple • s and of executions thereupon, a man may leavie Fines or not Quaere. 44. E. 3. 38. Br. Fines, &c. 22.
A Disseisee levies a Fine to a stranger, whether this gives the right to the Disseisor or not. Quaere. 2. Rep. fo. 56. a. 3. Rep. fo. 90. a. b. 6. Rep. fo. 70. a. See my Reports, pa. 105. pl. 180.

Tenant for life, the reversion to an Ideot, an Uncle Heire apparent to the Ideot, leavies a Fine and dies, Tenant for life dies, the Ideot dies, whether the Issue of the Uncle who leavied the Fine, shall be barred by it, or not, Quaere. See my Reports, pa. 94. pl. 164 & pa. 146. pl. 216.

div.head: Forfeiture of Lands, and Goods, and Offices.
div.p: WHether an Attachment in a Court Baron be forfeited by non-appearance of the party or not. Quaere. 28 H. 6. 9. Br. Attachment, &c. 2. 34. H. 6. 49. Br. Attachment, &c. 19.
Whether a Gardein of a Prison shall forfeit his Office by an Escape In the night or not. Quaere. 5. E. 4. 26. Br. Forfeiture, &c. 54.

Tenant for life, the remainder for life the remainder in Fee, Tenant for life makes a Feoffement in Fee, whether he in the remainder for life
may enter for the forfeiture or not. Quaere. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 252. a. Dyer, fo. 339. pl. 44. 29. Ass. pl. 64. 40. & 45. & 50. Ass. See Littleton, sect. 416. & 1. Rep. fo. 76. a. b.

div.head: Gardian in Socage.
div.p: TEnant in Socage devises by his will, the custodie of his Heire apparent within age to B. whether this shall barre the Gardian in Socage or not. Quaere. Keilway, fol. 186. pl. 1.

div.head: Grants of Common persons.
div.p: AN Executor grants omnia bona & catalla sua, whether this shall passe the goods of the Testator or not. Quaere. 10. E. 4. 1. Br. Grants 96. 46. E. 3. 18. Br. Grants 21. 24, E. 3. 35. Br. Executors 84. See my Reports, pa. 205.

An Abbot hath an Advowson appropriate, which hath a Vicarage endowed, and grants the Church and Advowson, whether by this the Advowson of the Vicarage, shall passe or not Quaere. 16. E. 3. Br. Judgements 138. See 40. E. 3. 28. Br. Jurisdiction 5. and Juris utrum 2.

A man grants omnia boni & catalla sua, whether by this an Obligation shall passe or not. Quaere. 25. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 5. pl. 3. 36. 37. H. 8. fo. 59. pl. 15. 21. H. 6. fo. 30. 8. Rep. fo. 33. a. b. 4. E. 6. Br. Grants 51. 39 H. 6. 35. Br. Grants 62. 4. H. 7. 10. Br. Grants 84.

div.head: Grants of the King.
div.p:
THe King grants a Mannour hominibus de f. heredibus & successoribus suis, rendring Rent Quaere. whether this shall make them a Corporation or not; and Quaere, if it were without rendring Rent. 21. E. 4. 55. 56. Br. Corporations, &c. 65. 2. H. 7. 13. Br. P • ttents 44. 7. E. 4. 30. Br. Pattents 62. 7.
E. 4. 14. Br. Pattents 85. Dy • r. fo. 100. pl. 70.
The King grants an Escheate cum acciderit, whether the Grant be good or not. Quaere. 1. & 2. P. &. M. Dyer. fo. 108. pl. 30.
The King grants a Copy-ho • d for life generally, whether this destroyes the Copy hold, or not. Quaere. See my Keports, pa. 226 pl. 246.

div.head: Heire.
div.p: VVHether the Heire of the Heire, or the Executors of the Heire, shall be charged in Debt upon an Obligation made by the Ancestor or not Quaere. Pl. Com • f • . 441. a. 22. of the Queene Dyer, fo. 368. pl. 46.

div.head: Incertainty.
div.p: A Man Distraines by two Horses, the one worth 10 l. the other 40 s. and avowes the one for one Rent day, the other for another, not making mention which for the one, nor which for the other, and the one is found for him, the other against him, of which horse he shall have a retourne. Quaere. 2. H. 6. fo. 3. a. See 2. H. 6. 17. Br. Retourne de avers 1.

div.head: Instance and Instant.
div.p: A Copie-holden for life Heriotable, the Lord grants the Seigniory for 99. yeares, if the Tenant should live so long, the Tenant dies, whether the Grantee for 99. yeares shall have the Heriot by force of this instant any title, or not. Quaere. See my Reports, pa. 23. pl. 52.

div.head: Joynder in Action.
div.p: The Goods of the Testator are taken out of the possession of the Executors, whether they ought to joyne or sever in action. Quaere. 42. E. 3. 26. Br. Executors 31. 2. H. 7. 15. 6. H. 7. 6. Br. Executors 170.
A promise is made to a Baron of a Feme Executrix, in that Right as Executrix, whether they may joyne in action or not. Quaere. See my Reports, pa. 72. pl. 110.

div.head: Joyntenants, &c.
div.p: IT is enacted by Parliament, That all Estates made to I. N. shall be void; an Estate is made to I. N. and his wife, whether this shall be void the wife surviving or not. Quaere. 5. H. 7. 30. Br. Joyntenants, &c. 67.

Two Joyntenants for life, the one makes a Lease for yeares, to commence after his death, and dies, whether this shall binde the Survivor or not. Quaere. Pl. Com. fo. 263. b. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 184. b. 185. a Littleton, sect. 289. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 186. a. b. See Dyer, fo. 69. pl. 30. and 279. pl. 7. and 187. pl. 5.
Two Joyntenants, the one grants a Rent to his compagnion in Fee, whether the Grant be good or not. Quaere. Keilway, fo. 728. pl. 95.

A man possessed of a tearme for yeares, devised by his Testament, the terme to his two Sons equally, whether they be Joyntenants, or Tenants in Common. Quaere. 28. H. 8. Dyer. fo. 25. pl. 158. See Ratcliffs Case, 3. Rep. fo. 39. b.

An Obligation of 200 l. is made to two solvend. e • s sc. the one hundred pounds to one of them, and the other hundred pounds to the other, the one of the Obligees dies, and his Executors
sue for the one hundrtd pounds, whether the intier 200 l. accrues to the Survivor or not Quaere. 18. of the Queene Dyer, fo. 347. pl. 20. See fo. 160. b. pl. 43.

div.head: Justification.
div.p: GRantee of a Rent Charge in Fee, distraines for Arrearages, and then grants it over, whether he ought to avow or justifie. Quaere. my Reports, pa. 103. pl. 178.

div.head: King and Que • ne.
div.p:
THe King grants Land to the Queene in Fee, whether • his be a good Grant or not Quaere. the Book of Entries 97. 98. Pl. Com. fo. 206. Sta
•… etons Case. See the Epistle to the •…
Rep. 3. H. 7. cap. 14 ob. 49 E. 40. Br. •… itle novability. See 34. H. 6. 34. Pl. •… om. fo. 245. 247. 234. 35. H. 6. 38.
•… ns. 17. E. 3. b. 7. H. 7. 7. 18. E. 3. 13. •…
Rep. Clarkes Case 4. Rep. Vernons Case,
8. of the Queene Dyer, fo. 248. 4. Rep. 3. 6. (against Br. 6. E. 6. Dower 69.) 23. E. 3. 22. 1. E. 3. 4. 9. E. 3. 33.

The Queene an Infant makes a Feoffement in Fee, whether this be good or not. Quaere. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 3. a. 133. a. b. 131. a. 127. a. and 31. b. 26. Ass. pl. 54. 3. H. 6. 55. 11. H. 6. 32. Pl. Com. fo. 213. & 221. F. N. B. fo. 43. 15. E. 4. 16. 38. E. 3. 2. Dyer, fo. 203. 27. Ass. pl. 4. 5. Rep. fo. 27. 18. E. 4. 10. 21. E. 4. 13. 8. Rep. 173. 6. Rep. 74. 27. H. 8. 1. 17. E. 3. 17. Stamfords Pleas of the Crowne, 61. 3. H. 7. 14. 21. H. 7. 8. 5. Rep. fo. 56. a. 9. E. 3. 33. 3. H. 7. 14. b.

div.head: Lachesse.
div.p: If the King hath a presentation in any other Right then in the Right of the Crowne, whether Laps shall incurre against him, as against any other person or not. Quaere. Register, fo. 31. a. Br. presentments al Esglises 156.

div.head: Leases.
div.p: A man covenants that another •… hall have his Land for twenty yeares, whether this amounts to a Lease or not. Quaere. 21. H. 7. 37. Br. Covenant, 26. and Lease 21. 37. H. 8. & 1. E. 6. Br. Lease 60. See Dyer, fo. 372 b. pl. 11. & fo, 150. pl. 83. See Hobarts Reports, pa. 48. b. 49. a.
A man makes a Lease for yeares tendring Rent to himselfe during the Tearme, and dies, whether his Heire shall have debt for the Rent arere after or not. Quare. See Title Reservation 1.

A Bishop makes a Lease to two for yeares rendring Rent, after makes a new Lease with confirmation of the Deane and Chapter to one of them, and dies, whether by his death the first Lease be wholly void or not. Quaere. 32. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 46. pl. 9.

A man makes a Lease for yeares, upon condition that if the Lessee aliens the terme, that then it should be lawfull to the Lessor, &c to enter the Lessee aliens the terme, the Lessor before entry makes a Lease for yeares, whether the Lease be good or not. Quaere. 28. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 6 pl. 1. & fo. 7. pl. 6. Pl. Com. fo. 131. 132. 133. &c.

Tenant in taile makes a Lease for yeares to commence after his death rendring Rent, and diess the Issue accepts the Rent, whether this shall barre his entry or not. Quaere. Dyer. fo. 279. pl. 7. fo. 69. pl. 130. & f • . 246. a. pl. 69. Co • ke upon Littleton, fo. 44. a. Pl. Com. f • . 430 See Dyer, fo. 357. pl. 43 the like case.

div.head: License.
div.p:
A Feme sole Licenses a man to hunt in her Warren and af e •… takes husband, whether by the inter marriage, the License be determined
or not. Quaere. 22. H. 6. 52. Br. Licenses 6.

A man licenses another to hunt and kill a Buck in his Parke, whether by force of this License he may take it away with him or not. Quaere. 18. E. 4. 14. Br. Licenses, &c. 12. and 6. And Quaere. whether he may kill it by his Servant or not. See 23 H. 8. Br. Pa
• ents 76. & 12. H. 7. 25. Br. Property 41. for the first case, and See 21. H. 7. 13. Br. Trespasse, 207. 13. H. 7. 10. Br. Trespasse 431.

div.head: Livery and Seisin.
div.p:
A Man makes a Feoffement and a Letter of Attorney to make li
•… ery absolutely, and he makes livery upon condition, whether this livery •… e void or not. Quaere. 12. Ass. pl. 24.
•… r. Disseisor &c. 33. and Feoffements 25.
•… ooke upon Littleton, fo. 250. a. b. Per
•… ns, fo. 39. pl. 192. Cooke upon Little
•… n, fo. 52. a. b. 26. Ass. pl. 39. Br. Fe
•… ffements 27.

A man infeoffes two, and makes a Letter of Attorney to one of them to make Livery to the other in the name of both, and he doth it, whether he that makes the livery doth take any thing by it or not. Quaere. 3. H. 6. 43. Br. Attorney 5. Perkins, fo. 41. a.

A man seized of a House and Close makes a Lease for years of the House; and after makes a Feoffement of the House and Close and delivers Seisin in the House (the Wife and Infants of the Termor being in the House) in the name of all, agreed that the House shall not passe, but whether the Close being within the view, shall passe or not. Quaere. 28. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 18. pl. 107. 108.

A Letter of Attorney is made to three to make livery, conjunctim & divisim, two make livery, the third being present, not doing or saying any thing, whether this be a good livery or not. Quaere. 38. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 62. pl. 34.

Lessee for yeares makes a Feoffement, and a Letter of Attorney to make Livery, and after the Attorney delivers Seisin, the Lessor being present upon the Land, not contradicting; whether the Land passes by this Feoffement or not. Quaere. Dyer, fo. 362. pl. 20. & 354. pl. 35.

div.head: Maintenance.
div.p: A Man buyes a Title thus, That if he can recover it, he shall pay two hundred pounds, otherwise nothing, whether this be maintenance punishable at the Common-Law or not. Quaere. Hobarts Reports, pa. 157. pl. 141.

div.head: Monies, and embasement of them.
div.p: A Man bound to pay money by specialty, tenders the money at the day of payment, which is refused, and after the money is debased, who shall beare the losse of it Quaere. 7. E. 6. Dyer, fo. 83. pl. 76. See before in Dyer, pl. 69. 70. 73, 74, 75. and Davis Reports, fo. 27, 28.
A man bequeatheth by his will money to another, after base money is established, whether the Legacy may be paid in this base money or not Quaere. Davis Reports, fo. 27. b.

A man hath a thousand pound pure silver in marriage with his wife, who after are divorsed causa prae-contractus. Or a man recovers by erronious judgement an hundred pound in debt, and hath execution in pure silver, after the judgement is reversed, if base money be established in the meane time; whether restitution in these
cases may be of base money or not Quaere. Davis Reports, fo. 27. b. 28. a.

div.head: Mortmaine.
div.p: IF a Rent be granted to an Abbot and his Successors for eighty yeers; whether this be Mortmaine or not. Quaere. 4. H. 6. 9. Br. Mortmaine 15. Pl. Com. fo. 87. a.

Whether the alienation of one spirituall or religious man to another spirituall man, be Mortmaine or not. Quaere. Keilway, fo. 111. pl. 37. 21. E. 3. 5. Br. Mortmaine 12. 11. H. 4. 88. Br. Mortmaine 18. 16. Ass. pl. 1. Br. Mortmaine 19.
Whether a Lord that is disseised at the time of the alienation in Mortmaine, shall have a yeare after his entry, for to enter for Mortmaine, or not. Quaere. Keilway, fo. 111. pl. 83.

div.head: Non est factum.
div.p: TWo are bound in an Obligation, and the Seale of one of them is broken off, in an aciton brought against the other, whether he may pleade Non est factum, or not. Quaere. 3. H. 7, 15. Br. Non est factum 21. See my Reports, pa. 125. pl. 205.

div.head: Obligation.
div.p: A Man was bound to I. N. that he should not use his Art in D. by two yeares, and by Hull this Obligation is against Law. Quaere of this, because that the restriction goes only to D. which is not a totall restriction. 2. H. 5. 5. Br. Faltz. 93. and Obligation 85. See the 8. Rep. fo. 125. b. and the 11. Rep. fo. 53. b. and see my Reports, pa. 77. pl. 121. pa. 191. pl. 238.

Two are bound in a Bond, and the Seale of one is broken off, whether
this shall avoid the whole deed, so that in an action brought against the other, he may pleade non est factum, or not. Quaere. 3. H. 7. 15. Br. Non est factum, 21. See, my Reports pa. 125. pl. 205.

A man is bound to a Baron and Feme, the Baron makes the wife Executrix and dies, whether the wife may bring an action as Executrix to the Baron, or whether she ought to bring it, Nomine proprio, as Surviyor, or not. Quaere, 4. H. 6. 5. Br. Obligation 35.

div.head: Occupans & Occupanti Conceditur.
div.p:
A Lease is made to one, his Executors, and assignes pur auter viae, the Lessee makes a Lease for yeares, rendring Rent to him, his Executors and Assignes, and dies. Quaere. Whether the Lessee for yeares shall be an Occupant, and the Rent extinct; or whether that the Freehold shall revert
to the first Lessor, and the terme be in esse 15. and 16. of the Queene Dyer, fo. 328. pl. 10. and see 38. H. 6. 4. And Quaere in this case whether the Executor shall be a speciall Occupant, or not.

div.head: Outlawry.
div.p: IN Debt brought against an Executor, he pleads Outlawry in the Testator, whether this be a good plea or not. Quaere. 8. E. 4. 6. Br. Ʋtlagory, 49. 3. H. 6. 17. and 32. 32. H. 6. 27.

div.head: Parcell and not Parcell.
div.p: WHether a hundred may be parcell of a Manour or nor. Quaere. 27. H. 6. 2. Br. Parcel, &c. 2. and Br. Scire facias, 7. Keilway, fo. 151. pl. 51.
Whether an Annuity may be parcell of a Priory or not. Quare. 22. E. 4. 44. Br. Parcell, &c. 26.

div.head: Possibility.
div.p: A. By Indenture infeoffes B. of black acre, to the use of A. for life, the remainder in taile to C. the remainder in fee to D. with a proviso, if E. dies without issue, that A. at any time by Indenture sealed, &c. in presence of foure witnesses, may alter, &c any use, &c. A. by Indenture renounces Surrenders, Releases, &c. to B. C. and D. the said Power, Condition, Authority, &c. E. dies without Issue, A. by Indenture in presence of 4. Revokes the first uses, and limits new, whether this release of a future possibility, or power of revocation shall barre it or not. Quaere. 1. Rep. Albanies Case. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 265. b.

div.head: Presentments to Churches.
div.p: A Presentment is divolved to a Bishop by Laps, who is deprived, whether the Metropolitan or the King shall present. Quaere. 7. E. 6. Dyer, fo. 87. pl. 103.

div.head: Prohibition.
div.p: A Man devises that his Executors shall sell his Land, and of the Monies shall give such portions to his Daughters, the Legatees sue in Court Christian for their portions, whether a Prohibition lyes or not. Quaere. 4. and 5. P. and M. Dyer, fo. 151. pl. 5. Trin. 9. of the Queene Dyer, fo. 264. pl. 41. See Hobarts Reports. pa. 371. pl. 343.

div.head: Rationabile parte bonorum.
div.p: WHether it be Communis lex Angliae, for women and Infants to have their reasonable part of the Goods of the Defuncte or not. Quaere. See Br. Rationabile parte honorum per totum, and see F. N. B. the Writ of Rationabile parte bonorum.

div.head: Recognizance
div.p: WHether the Commons House of Parliament may take a Recognizance or not. Quaere. 1. H. 7. 20. Br. Recognizance 8.

div.head: Record, and matter of that.
div.p:
A Man brought Debt upon a Recovery in a Court Baron whether the Defendant may pleade Nul tiel Recorde, or whether he ought to say, Nul tiel Recovery ot not. Quaere. 34.
H. 6. 49. Br. Court Baron, &c. 1. 34. H. 6. 42. Br. Court Baron 14. 9. E. 4. 14. Br. Court Baron 16. 28, Ass. pl. 14. Br. Record, &c. 66. F. N. B. fo. 71. Br. Recorde &c. 70. See my Reports, pag. 15.
• l. 35.

div.head: Relation.
div.p: THe Father is disseised, the Sonne makes a Release, and delivers it as an Escroule, to be delivered over to the Disseisor at the death of the Father, the Father dies, the Deed is bayled to the Disseisor; whether this second Delivery shall relate to the first, and so avoid the Deed or not. Quaere. 35. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 57. pl. 23. See the 3. Rep. fo. 35. b. See Title Countermand 1.

div.head: Releases.
div.p: WHether a Release of a right upon a condition subsequent be good or not. Quaere. See Title Conditions.

Whether a Release of all Actions reall, be a good Barre in an Annuity or not. Quaere. Cooke upon Littleton, f • . 374. b. Dyer, fo. 14O. pl. 40. 19. H. 6. 37. 2. H. 4. 13. Br. Annuity, 13. & 43. L. 5. E. 4. 40. Br. Annuity 34. 21. E. 4. 83. Br. Annuity 39. 11. H. 7. 20. Br. Annuity 54 Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 2. a. and 285. a.
Feme Disseisoresse takes husband, the Disseisee releases to the Baron and his Heires, whether this shall inure to him or to his wife, or not. Quaere. 14. H. 8. 4. 21. H. 6. 41. Keilway, fo. 129. a.

A. By Indenture infeoffes B. of black Acre, to the use of A. for
life, the remainder in taile to C. the remainder in Fee to D. with a proviso, if E. dies without Issue, that A. at any time by Indenture sealed, &c. in presence of foure Witnesses, may alter, &c. any use &c. A. by Indenture renounces Surrenders, Releases, &c. to B. C. and D. the said power, condition, authority, &c. E. dies without Issue, A. by Indenture in presence of foure Witnesses, revokes the first uses, and limits new, whether this r • lease of a future possibility, or power of revocation, shall barre it or not Quaere. 1. Rep. Albaines Case. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 265. b.

Two men are bound joyntly and severally to a third, who sues the Bond, against both, and after appearance enters a Retraxit against one of them, whether this shall amount to a Release, so that it shall discharge the other or not. Quaere. See my Reports pa. 95. pl. 165.

Where one Coparcener of a Rent marries the Ter-tenant, and the other
releases to the husband and wife, how it shall inure. Quaere. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 273. b.
Where the Feme Mesne and the Tenant entermarry, and the Lord Paramount releases to the husband and wife, how it shall inure. Quaere. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 280. a.

div.head: Remainder.
div.p: WHether there may be a Remainder of a Rent de novo, or not. Quaere. See Title Rents 2.

div.head: Remitter.
div.p: TEnant in Taile infeoffes his Issue inheritable to the Taile within age, who at full age makes a Lease for yeares, Tenant in Taile dies, whether the Lease be avoided by the Remittor or not. Quaere. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 349. a. 33. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 51. h.

div.head: Rents.
div.p: WHether a Rent granted not of customary Lands. as out of Lands devisable, Gavelkinde or Borough English, or the like, shall be of the nature of the Land, or not. Quaere. 22. Ass. pl. 78. Br. Customes 34. and Rents 13. 26. H. 8. 4. Br. Customes 1. 21. H. 6. 10 and 11. Br. Customes 24.4. E. 3. 32. Br. Customes 58. 14. H. 8. 7. Br. Customes 65. and Br. Rents 6. and 20. 26. H. 8. Dyer. pl. 1. and fo. 140. pl. 38. and 153. pl. 11. and 192. pl. 23. See Cooke upon Lirtleton, fo. 111. a. for devise of a Rent see now the Statute.

Whether there may be a remainder of a Rent de novo, or not. Quaere. 7. H. 4. 4. Br. Done & Remainder 8. 15. E. 4. 9. Br. Done & Remainder, 54. 8. H. 4. 19. Br. Done & Remainder, 58. Pl. Com. fo. 35. a. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 298. a. 2. Rep. fol. 70. 76. and 78. 3. E. 3. See Cooke upon Littleton, before, 14. H. 7. 2. Br. Surrender 16. And see the ease immediately following.

A man recovers a Rent by Writ of Entry against Tenant in Taile of a Rent which had not being before the Grant made in Taile, whether the Recoveror shall have a Fee simple or not. Quaere. 15. E. 4. 6. and 8. See 37. H. 6. 36 and Pl. Com. fo. 557. a.
Land of B. out of which a Rent is issuing, is given to another by Act of Parliament; whether the Rent be by this extinguished or not. Quaere. 21. H. 7. 3. Br. Parliament 28.

The Lord receives his Rent upon Christmas day Before dinner, and dies after dinner, and the Lord holds of the King, whether the King shall have the Rents of the Tenants arreare or not. Quaere. 44. E. 3. 3. Br. Presentments to Churches 4. and Br. Rents 2.
A man makes a Lease for yeares rendring Rent to himselfe during the terme, and dies, whether his Heire shall have debt for the Rent arreare after, or not. Quaere. See Title reservations.

div.head: Requests.
div.p: A. is bound to B. to deliver to him two hundred weight of Hops, and B. to chuse them out of twenty foure bags, &c. whether B. is bound to request A. to shew the bags for him to make his Election or not. Quaere. See my Reports, pa. 74. pl. 113.

div.head: Remitter.
div.p: TEnant in Taile infeoffes his Son and Heire inheritable to the Taile, within age at the time of the Feoffement, who at full age makes a Lease for yeares by Deed Indented, or Deed Poll of the Land, and then Tenant in Taile dies, so that he is remitted, whether he shall avoid the Lease or not. Quaere Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 349. a. 33. H. 8. Dyer. fo. 51. b. See Littleton, Sect. 289.

A husband discontinues the Land
of his wife, and goeth beyond Sea, and the Discontinuee lets the same Land to the wife for terme of her life, and delivers seisin to her, and after the husband comes back, and disagrees to the Lease and Livery of Seisin made to his wife in his absence; whether this shall ouste the wife of her Remitter, or not. Quaere. Littleton Sect. 677. See Cooke thereupon.

A Husband discontinues the Lands of his wife, and the discontinuee is disseised, by the coven and consent of the husband and wife, and aft r the Disseisor letteth the same Lands to the husband and wife for life, whether in this case the wife shall be remitted or not. Quaere. Littleton, Sect. 678. See Cooke thereupon, fo. 357. b.

Two Joyntenants in Fee, the one of full age, the other within age, are disseised, and the Disseisor dies seised, and his Issue enters, the Joyntenant of full age dies; whether the Infant surviving may enter into the whole or not. Quaere. See Littleton, sect. 696. and Cooke thereupon, fo. 364. b.

div.head: Reservations.
div.p: A Man makes a Lease for yeares, rendring Rent to himse fe during the terme, and dies; whether his Heire shall have Debt for Rent arreare after, or not. Quaere. 27. H. 8. 19. Perkins 697. 698. 699. 22 H. 7. fo. 88. b. Keilway, 5. Rep. fo. 111. a. Mallories Case, Pl. Com. fo. 171. a. 21. H. 7. 25. 30. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 45. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 47. a. q.

Whether a condition of re entry may be reserved to the Heire, not naming the Ancestor, or not. Quaere. for I doubt of it, upon the words of Littleton, sect. 346. and 343. See Cooke thereupon, fo. 213. and 214.

div.head: Retorne of Beasts.
div.p:
A Man distraines by two Horses, the one worth 10 l. and the other 40 s. and he avowes the one for one
Rent day, and the other for another, not making mention which for the one, nor which for the other, and the one is found for him the other against him. Quaere. of which horse he shall have returne. 2. H. 6. fo. 3. See 2. H. 6. 17. Br. Retourne & avers 1.

div.head: Revocation.
div.p: THe King presents his Clerke to a Benefice, and before institution presents another, whether this be a revocation of the former presentation, or not. Quaere. See my Rep. pa. 86.

div.head: Seisin.
div.p: A Man who hath a Rent grants it over upon condition, the condition is broken; whether the Grantor shall have an Assize for the Rent after arreare, without a new Seisin, or not. Quaere. M. 15. E. 3. Br. Title Assize 407. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 202. b. 15. Ass. 12.

A man hath Issue a Sonne and a Daughter by one venter, and a Sonne by another venter, and makes a Lease for life rendring Rent and dies; whether the receit of the Rent shall be a sufficient Seisin to make a possessio fratris, so that the Daughter shall inherit, or not. Quaere. 35. Ass. Pl. 2. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 15. a. 14. E. 2. Br. Seisin 43.

A man dies seized of severall acres of Land in one County, his Heire enters generally in one of the Acres, whether this gives possession of the other Acres or not. Quaere, 21. H. 7. 33. a. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 15. a. b. See 39. Ass. pl. 16.

div.head: Statute.
div.p:
WHether a Baron of the Realme may acknowledge a Statute or not Quaere. See 5 E 4. 108. 8. R. 2. proces. 224. 5. E. 4. 100. a. 9. E. 3. Bre. 473. 39 E. 3. 35. b. Dyer, fo. 360. 9. Rep. fo. 117. 10. H. 4. 15. D. 1. H. 5. 14. 27.
H. 8. 22. 14. H. 7. 21. 26. H. 8. 7. 14. H. 6. 2. 27. H. 8. 22 35. H. 6. 146. Dyer, fo. 314. 48. Ass. pl. 6. 27. E. 3. ca. 1. de premunire. 15. H. 7. 9. b. 9 E. 4. fo. 2. 6. Rep, fo. 52. 15. E. 3. ca. 26. 5. H 4. ca. 8. 3. H. 6. fo. 48. per Cockin, 9 Rep. fo. 69. 12 H. 7. 25. To the objection, that if a Baron cannot acknowledge a Statute, that it is void if he shall answer, 'tis not void, for debt lies. 7. E. 4. 27. or 24. F. N. B. 122. 22. E. 4. 22.

div.head: Surrender.
div.p:
A Termor agrees, that his Lessor shall make a Feoffement to a stranger, whether this be a surrender or not. Quaere. 21. H. 7. 7. Br. Surrender 48. 28. &.
