• 9. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 33. pl. 13. 14, 15, 16. See 40 E. 3. 24. Br. Surrend • r, 1. 8. Ass. Br. Surrender 25. 40. Ass. pl. 16. Br. Surrender, 35. See Dyer, fo. 363. pl. 22. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 48. b.

The King Leases a Messuage for yeares rendring Rent, the Lessee after
takes a patent of the office of the custody of the said messuage; whether the terme be surrendered or not. Quaere. Pasch. 3. of the Queene Dyer, fo. 200. pl. 62.

div.head: Taile.
div.p: GRandfather, Father, and Sonne, Lands are given to the Grandfather and to his Heires begotten by the Father, the Father dieth the Grandfather dieth, whether the Son be in as Heire to the Grandfather begotten upon the body of his Father; and whether the wife of the Grandfather in that case shall be endowed or not Quaere. 12. H. 4 2. per Horton. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 20. b.

Lands are given to a man and his wife, and to one Heire of their bodies lawfully begotten, and to one Heire of the bodie of that Heire only; whether this be an Estate Taile or not. Quaere. for I doubt of it 39. Ass. pl. 20. 20. H. 6. 35. 5. H. 4. 7. b.
14. H. 4. 15. Littleton, sect. 13. and Cooke thereupon, fo. 19. a. and fo. 20. a. b. and fo. 22. a.
A man gives Land to another, & haeredi masculo de corpore suo, what Estate this is. Quaere. Fide Registrum judiciale, fo. 6.

A man devises Land to a man, and to the Heires Males of his body, who hath Issue a Daughter, who hath Issue a Son, whether this Son be inheritable by force of this Devise, or not. Quaere. See Littleton, sect. 719. 1. H. 6. 24. 11. H. 6. 13. 14. 28. H. 6. Title Devise 18. Statham. Pl. Com. fo. 414. b. 20. H. 6. 43. 37. H. 8. Br. Title Done & Remainder 61. Title Nosme, 1. & 40. Perkins 506. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 25. a. b.

Lands are devised to one for life, the remainder to the next Heire Male of B. in taile, B. hath Issue two Daughters, and each of them hath Issue a Son, and the Father and Daughters die; whether the remainder be void for the incertaint • whether the eldest
shall take it because he is worthiest or whether both of them shall take, for that they both make but one Heire. Quaere. 11. H. 6. 13. 9. H. 6. 25. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 25. b.

Land is given to the Son, and to rhe Heires of the body of his Father (then dead) ingendered, this is a good Taile in him, but whether his younger brother shall inherit by force of this gift, or not. Quare. M. 4. &. 5. P. & M. Dyer, fo. 156.
• l. 24. 25. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 26. b. Hill. 8. of the Queene Dyer, fo. 247. pl. 76. See 12. H. 4 1. & 2. Br. Tai • e 10.

A Rent is granted in Taile, whether the Grantee may make it an Annuity, or not; because he seemes to have an election secundum formam doni, to take it as a Rent Charge, or as an Annuity; and the Statute De donis conditionalihus ses, that Voluntas donatoris in carta sua manifeste expressa de caetero observetur; and his will is observed by making it an Annuity or a Rent Charge; for he gave him by the Grant such an
implicit power. To this it may be said, That if he might at his Election make it an Annuity, then it were no more an Intaile, but a Fee conditionall as at Common Law, and then after Issue had, he may alien, and barre the Issue, which seemeth contrary to the will of the Donor, ideo Quaere.

Tenant in Taile makes a Lease for yeares, to commence after his death, rendring Rent, the Issue accepts the Rent; whether this shall barre his Entry or not. Quaere. Dyer, fo. 279. a. pl. 7. fo. 69. a. pl. 30. fo. 246. a. pl. 69. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 44. a. Pl. Com. fo. 430.

Tenant in Taile makes a Lease for yeares, rendring 20 s. Rent, and after releases 19 s. and dies, and the Issue accepts 12 d. whether he may distraine for the 19 s. more, or not. Quaere. 13. & 14. of the Queene Dyer, f. 304. pl. 53.

div.head: Tenant at will and sufferance.
div.p: TEnant at will is ousted, and the Lessor disseised, whether by this the Lease at will be determined or not. Quaere. 38. H. 6. 27. Br. Tenant pro copie, &c. 6. 11. E. 4. 3. Br. Tenant pro copie, &c. 11.

Whether Tenant at will may determine his will, a day or two before the Feast, in which he ought to pay his Rent, and thereby be excused of the payment of it, or not. Quaere. 20. H. 7. fo. 65. pl. 6. Keilway. See Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 55. b. letter. c.
Whether a bargainee before Inrollment, or Entry, shall be a Tenant at will, or not. Quaere See my Reports, pa. 62. pl. 97. & pa. 69. pl. 108. See Littleton, sect. 70.

div.head: Tenures.
div.p: TEnant by Knight service makes a gift in Taile, reserving Fealty and Rent; whether the Donee in Taile shall hold by Knight Service, and the other Services especially reserved, or in Socage onely. Quaere. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 23. a. 33. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 52. pl. 3. See Dyer, fo. 45. pl. 1.

div.head: Testaments.
div.p: WHether a Feme Covert may make a Testament without agreement of her husband, of things in action, as Obligations, and the like, due to her before the Coverture, or not. Quaere. 4. H. 6. 31. Br. Testament, &c. 9. 39. H. 6. 27. Br. Testament 10. 12. H. 7. 22. 23. 24. Br. Testament 11. 18. E 4. 11. Br. Testament 13. 5. E. 2. Br. Testament 21. See 4. Rep. fo. 61. a. 5. Rep. fo. 10. Dyer, fo. 354. b. pl. 34.

div.head: Time.
div.p: WHether a Gardian of a Prison shall forfeit his Office for an escape in the night, or not. Quaere. 5. E. 4. 26. Br. Forfeiture, &c. 54.

div.head: Tryall.
div.p: A Man is mortally wounded in France, and dieth thereof in Enland, whether an Appeale in this case (for it is not punishable by the Common Law) doth lye upon the Statute of 1. H. 4. cap 14 or not. Quaere. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 74. a. b.

An Earle or Lord of Ireland commits Treason in Ireland by open Rebellion whether he may be arraigned and put to his Tryall in England for the offence, by the Statute of 26. H. 8. cap. 13. 32. H. 8. cap. 4. 35. H. 8. 2. or 5. E. 6. 11. or not. Quaere. 19. and 20. of the Queene Dyer, fo. 360. pl. 6. Cooke
upon Littleton, fo. 261. b. See the 7. Rep. fo. 15. b.

div.head: Tythes.
div.p: A Parson Leases parcell of his glebe Land for yeares, rendring Rent, whether the Lessee shall pay Tythes or not. Quaere. 30. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 43. pl. 21.

The Inhabitants of a Parish have a Chappell of Fase, and a Custome that those within such a Precinct ought to finde a Rope for the third Bell, and to repaire part of the Mother Church, in consideration of which they have been freed from payment of any Tythes to the Mother Church, whether this be a good Custome or not. Quaere. See my Reports, pa. 91. pl. 151.

div.head: Vest and Devest.
div.p: A Mannour was given to S. by Parliament, and after a Tenant who held of it by Knights Service, died after S. was attainted of Treason, and the first Act reversed in all points, the King seized the Mannour, and granted it to his mother, whether the Patentee shall have the said Ward, or not, because it was a thing vested. Quaere. 3. H. 7. 15. Br. Parliament 39. See 4. H. 7. 10. Br. Parliament 41. Dyer, fo. 25. pl. 163. See Keilway, fo. 125. pl. 86. 21. H. 6. 56. Br. Presentments, &c. 22.

A Disseisee of a Mannour suffers the Disseisor to be in possession untill a Ward fals, and after re-enters, who shall have the Ward. Quaere. 2. H. 7. 2. Br. Garde 65. See Dyer, fo. 25. pl. 163. and the cases immediatly before.

div.head: View.
div.p: A Precipe quod reddat is brought against two, the one acknowledges the Action and the other demands the View; whether he shall have it, or not. Quaere. 14. H. 6. 5. Br. Dilatories 9. and View 68.

div.head: Villeinage and Villeine.
div.p: A Freeman marries a Niese, whether this be an Enfranchisement for ever, or for life onely. Quaere. The Lad marries his Niese, whether this be an Enfranchisement for ever, or no. Quaere. See Title Enfranchisement.

div.head: Voucher.
div.p:
THe Tenant vouched A. who is returned dead, upon the Writ of Summons; whether he may now vouch in another Line, or not. Quaere.
41. E. 3. 28. Br. Counterplea de Voucher 56. and Br. Voucher 18. 43. E. 3. 3. Br. Voucher 21.

div.head: Ʋse and Ʋses.
div.p: A Man in consideration of marriage, covenants, That immediately after his death, his Land shall inure and remaine to his Sonne, whether this raises a use immediately to the Sonne, or not. Quaere. 34. and 35. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 55. pl. 3. and 4. Mich. 1. M. Dyer, fo. 96. pl. 41. Dyer, fo. 162. pl. 48. and 49. fo. 235 pl 20, 21. fo. 166. pl. 8. and 9. fo. 325. pl. 37. and fo. 190. pl. 18.

div.head: Wager of Law.
div.p: A Man brings Debt upon a Recovery in ancient Demesne which is a Court Baron; whether the Defendant may wage his Law, or not. Quaere. 34. H. 6. 49. Br. Court Baron, &. 1. Leygager 11. and Record, &c. 8. 1. H. 7: 25. Br. Leygager. 105. See my Reports, pa. 15. pl. 35.
By the Custome of London a man cannot wage his Law for bourding, but whether in an Action brought at Westminster he shall have his Law, or not. Quaere See Title Customes 1.

div.head: Warde.
div.p: A Man of non sane memory makes a Feoffement and dies, his Heire recovers by a Dum non fuit compos mentis, whether he shall be in Warde or not. Quaere. 7. H. 4. 12. Br. Garde 24.
Disseisee of a Mannour suffers the Disseisor to continue possession till a Warde fals and after re enters; who shall have the Warde. Quaere. 2. H. 7. 2. Br. Garde, 65. See Keiway, fo. 111 pl. 83.

A Mannour was given to S. by Parliament, and after a Tenant which held of it by Knights Service died, after S. was attainted of Treason, and the Act reversed by Parliament in all points, the King seized the Mannour,
and granted it to his mother; wheth •• the Patentee shall have the Ward, or not. Quaere. 3. H. 7. 15. Br. Parliament, 39. See 4. H. 7. 10. Br. Parliament 41. See Title Vest & Devest.
Tenant in Socage devises by his will, the custody of his Heire apparent within age to B. whether this shall barre the Gardian in Socage, or not. Qu • re. Keilway, fo. 186. pl. 1.

A man seized in Fee before the Statute of 27. H. 8. infeoffes B. in Fee, to the use of him and his wife, and the Heires of their two bodies ingendered, and for default of such Issue, to the use of the Feoffer and his Heires in Fee, after the Statute they have Issue, the husband dies, the Issue within age; whether he shall be in Ward during the life of his mother, or not. Quaere. 3. & 4. P. & M. Dyer, fo. 133. pl. 6. See 28. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 7. pl. 11.

div.head: Warranty.
div.p: WHether a man may grant a Rent de novo out of Land for life, or &c. with warranty, because there can be no Title precedent to the Rent. Quaere. 2 H. 4. 13. 30. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 42. Temps. E. 1. Admeasurement 16. 32. E. 1. Voucher, 294. 30 E. 1. Exchange 16. 9. E. 4. 15. E. 4. 9. 29. Ass. 13.

A man infeoffes another of an Acre of Land with Warranty, and dieth seized of another Acre, having Issue a Sonne and a Daughter by one venter, and a Sonne by another, the eldest Sonne entreth and dieth, the Land discends to the Sister; In this case the Warranty discendeth on the Sonne, and he may be vouched as Heire, and the Sister as Heire of the Land; in which case the Sonne and Heire by the Comman Law having nothing by discent, the whole losse of the recovery in value lieth upon the Heire of the Land, albeit he be no
Heire to the Warranty. Then put the case that there is a Warranty Paramount, who shall deraigne that Warranty? and to whom shall the recompence in value go? Quaere. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 376. b. Pl. Com. fo. 515.

Land was devised to the Father for life, the remainder to the next Heire Male of the Father, and to the Heires Males of his body, the Devisor dies, the Father infeoffed B. with Warranty; by the Feoffement the contingent remainder is destroyed, but whether the Warranty shall binde the remainder, or not. Quaere. 1. Rep. Archers Case.

A Servant sels Clothes, and warrants them; whether deceit lies against him, or not Quaere. The sale being the sale of the Master, and the warrant the warrant of the Servant. 11. H. 4. 6. Br. Deceit, 29. and Garranty 61.

A man knowing a thing to be corrupt and naught, sels it, whether
Deceit lies against him for the knowledge, without Warranty, or not. Quaere. 20. H. 6. 34. Br. Deceit; 2. 9. H. 6. 53. Br. Garranty 93.

div.head: Waste.
div.p: IF a man fix a Furnace or Fats in medio domus, and not to the wals, or a post in the Land not to the wals, he may take it away within the Terme; but if he suffer it till the Terme be ended, the Lessor shall have it; and the taking of them by the Termer within his Terme is not waste, for the house is not impaired by it, by Kings Mile Justice, and Grevil Serjeant, quod nullus negavit. Tamen Quaere. 21. H, 7. 26. Br. Chattels, &c. 7. See Br. Chattels, &c. 11.

Tenant for yeares commits wast, and after surrenders to him in the reversion, who accepts it, excepting the waste, whether an Action of waste lies, or not. Quaere. 19. H. 6.
66. Br. Waste 86. 14. H. 8. 10, 11. Br. Waste 95. 23. H. 8. Br. Waste 138. 14. H. 6. 14. pl. 48. See Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 285. a.

A man makes a Lease for life of a House and Land, which House was ruinous at the time of the Demisee made, the Lessee cuts downe Trees to repaire it, whether this be a justifiable waste, or not. Quare. 12. H. 8. 1. 29. H. 8. Dyer, fo. 36. a. Cooke upon Littleton, fo. 53. a. letter, g. and fo. 55. b. letter, a.
